<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Flife%20sciences%2Four%20insights%2Fupgrading%20medtech%20commercial%20operations%20in%20china%2Fupgrading-medtech-commercial-operations-in-china.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="upgrading-medtech-commercial-operations-in-china" data-layer-report-name="upgrading-medtech-commercial-operations-in-china>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (8 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Chinas burgeoning market</strong> for medtech, estimated at $70 billion in 2021,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="59f78886-fbcd-4b9d-8520-f6622087bd45"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="59f78886-fbcd-4b9d-8520-f6622087bd45" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of National Health Commission (NHC) data and annual reports regarding revenue of more than 150 medtech companies and their market share.</span></span></span></a></span> could more than double this decade if the governments Healthy China 2030 plan stays on track. The plan projects 9 percent annual spending growth through this decade.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ca0e58a-f514-465e-8064-20da9550ac37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ca0e58a-f514-465e-8064-20da9550ac37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of National Health Commission (NHC) data and annual reports regarding revenue of more than 150 medtech companies and their market share.</span></span></span></a></span> This is significant. That growth would lift Chinas healthcare spending as a percentage of GDP to almost equal footing with some developed economies in Europe and would lift Chinas medtech market to about 20 percent of the global market by 2030.</p>
<p>China could remain the worlds most appealing growth market for medtech. The growth pace, however, has slowed, and uncertainties facing business leaders are likely to continue. While multinational medtech participants in China and domestic companies in this critical industry continue to deliver essential healthcare goods and services, they need to rethinkand, in most cases, restructuretheir commercial operations in response to the new market dynamics.</p>
<h2>The old model was geared for rapid (even sprawling) expansion</h2>
<p>Many multinational companies (MNCs) and domestic companies in Chinas once surging medtech market thrived under a commercial model that valued multiple layers in the sales force and sprawling networks of numerous distributors; financial rigor was secondary. The old model came into fashion when annual growth rates for the industry averaged 15 percent in the first decade of this century and more than 10 percent in the second decade (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/upgrading%20medtech%20commercial%20operations%20in%20china/mck226009-china-medtech-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Chinas macro healthcare agenda is shifting to a new model." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/upgrading%20medtech%20commercial%20operations%20in%20china/mck226009-china-medtech-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>This model needs to be reexamined. Medtech companies could look to redeploy resources with financial discipline in ways that sustain growth, improve efficiency, and deliver better products and services to customers and patients. They are operating in a new pricing and competitive landscape that has more diverse stakeholders and requires more discipline and innovation.</p>
<p>In some areas, domestic companies are markedly improving their performance across their operations. Chinas 134 listed medtech companies generated $44 billion in 2021 revenues, an impressive CAGR of 36 percent since 2019nearly triple the markets overall rate of growth. More than five Chinese medtech companies have obtained the FDAs breakthrough designation, which helps expedite the development, assessment and review of novel medical devices that can potentially provide more effective treatment or that diagnose life-threatening or irreversibly debilitating diseases or conditions.</p>
<h2>Policy reforms have shifted the old model</h2>
<p>Overall GDP growth in China slowed to 3.0 percent in 2022 and is expected to rise only modestly to 4.5 to 5.5 percent in 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ba69ed6-6f87-48c5-89ad-c06501ecd3c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ba69ed6-6f87-48c5-89ad-c06501ecd3c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The director of the National Bureau of Statistics answered reporters questions on the national economic operation in 2022, National Bureau of Statistics, January 17, 2023. Baseline forecast is based on McKinsey analysis of data from several analyst houses, January 2, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The government paid high prices for medtech equipment and services, which were a factor in attracting many of the worlds leading MNCs to China in the last two decades. However, after years of generous criteria for payments, recent reforms in the governments procurement and medical insurance programs have shifted much of the old model. For example, the price for drug-eluting stents used in cardiac surgery was cut by more than 90 percent after reforms in 2021, decreasing to $100 from a previous range of $1,400 to $2,100.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b908d2e5-4f4b-4cb6-9f0f-cfccfd3d0341"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b908d2e5-4f4b-4cb6-9f0f-cfccfd3d0341" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Chinas high-value consumables industry has officially entered the era of volume-based procurement, China Association for Medical Devices Industry, July 22, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, hospitals face significant cost constraints, especially for less differentiated, commoditized products.</p>
<h2>Five levers for transforming the medtech commercial model in China</h2>
<p>Multinational and domestic medtech companies could consider reevaluating their commercial model to sustain or increase growth in China, focusing on five interlinked functions in operations:</p>
<!-- -->
<ul>
    <li>channel restructuring to prepare for the price-sensitive environment while expanding coverage to sustain the growth</li>
    <li>commercial resources reassessment to adapt to evolving strategic priorities and outperform the market</li>
    <li>omnichannel customer engagement to improve sales efficiency, broaden reach, and enhance customer experience</li>
    <li>ecosystem partnerships to develop new innovation engines and deliver integrated solutions to a broader customer base</li>
    <li>a focus on the basics to cope with margin pressure and the rise of local players</li>
</ul>
<p>Which of these levers is most difficult to pull? Which one can be a source of competitive advantage even for companies that have already started channel reforms or partnership scouting? There isnt a singular answer. The optimal response will vary by segments and companies. Business leaders will need to explore suitable approaches with appropriate levels of emphasis and execution.</p>
<p>In our view, complex channel restructuring is most urgent for companies that relied heavily on high-markup distributors and for those whose portfolios were most affected by the  government-mandated price drop (reforms known as volume-based procurement [VBP]<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="41a4f566-141c-4009-8fc9-c76c03197f71"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="41a4f566-141c-4009-8fc9-c76c03197f71" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These tenders are for contracts issued through the governments VBP reforms, which could be at national, provincial, or city levels across products.</span></span></span></a></span>). That said, VBP has created opportunities to serve broader markets. To tap into them, companies will also need effective ways to acquire new customers and retain existing ones via an omnichannel approach. Moreover, innovating through license-in and partnership agreements can help propel sustainable growth in the mid to long term. As VBP and trends in the macroeconomy ease the overall pace of revenue momentum in medtech, companies need to plan now to avoid having to continually put out fires in the near term.</p>
<p>Companies will also need to strengthen capabilities along the levers. For example, companies that have historically focused on consumables and that are now seeking to add equipment into their portfolio will need to recruit distributors with experience in engaging nonclinical stakeholders. They will also need to reassess their sales capabilities and resource allocation.</p>
<p>Great companies excel in this analysis. They can assess early the development needs for each lever, precisely identify the real source of advantage, efficiently transform commercial capabilities and models, and successfully outpace market growth.</p>
<h3>Restructuring the channels for customer touch points</h3>
<p>In a nation with more than 36,500 hospitals to care for 1.4 billion people,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a1fd7ab-7f81-4984-ae25-5ae0ca22155f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a1fd7ab-7f81-4984-ae25-5ae0ca22155f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Number of medical and health institutions nationwide by the end of November 2021, National Health Commission, January 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> the landscape of medtech companies and distributors has been fragmented. Distributors, together with the internal sales force of manufacturers, have largely acted as representatives to manufacturers customers, the hospitals, and clinics.</p>
<p>Two forces in the new economics of Chinas healthcare system are upending these roles and responsibilities. First, VBP is sharply reducing margins left to distributors. Bidders are expected to cut price-to-hospital<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f93e4adc-1426-4804-a7e6-e4b5bd08fa39"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f93e4adc-1426-4804-a7e6-e4b5bd08fa39" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Price-to-hospital is the price set by distributors when selling medtech products directly to hospitals.</span></span></span></a></span> by more than 50 percent to win contracts. Second, as they pertain to medical insurance payments, reforms<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e88d19f9-6e64-48ac-b11c-df86ecbcf564"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e88d19f9-6e64-48ac-b11c-df86ecbcf564" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Reforms in the governments DRG/DIP will lower healthcare payments through 2025 in all Chinese cities. DRG/DIP reforms affect 70 percent of the governments basic medical insurance funding, which covers medical expenses for 97 percent of the population. This is based on the <em>Three-year action plan for DRG/DIP payment reform</em>, issued by Chinas National Healthcare Security Administration (NHSA) in December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> tied to diagnosis-related group or diagnosis intervention packet (DRG/DIP) have a compounding effect in reducing the profit margins of manufacturers and distributors. In certain product categories, smaller distributors that are unable to navigate these shifts profitably have already walked away. Distribution consolidation  is evident. Sinopharm, for example, the largest healthcare distributor in China, reported a 21 percent increase to $17 billion for medtech revenues in 2021. Its expanding customer roster of manufacturers includes global leaders such as Medtronic, Johnson & Johnson, Danaher, Becton Dickinson, Stryker, and Smith+Nephew.</p>
<p>Medtech companies are responding to reforms by reevaluating their relationships with distributors. Roles and responsibilities are being reshaped as more companies are adapting to the new economics and sharply lowering payments they can offer distributors (Exhibit 2). Some have narrowed the tasks for platform distributors to only managing logistics and handling accounts receivable.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/upgrading%20medtech%20commercial%20operations%20in%20china/mck226009-china-medtech-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Companies roles and responsibilities with distributors are being reshaped as they adapt to new economics." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/upgrading%20medtech%20commercial%20operations%20in%20china/mck226009-china-medtech-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Since VBP reforms created the potential for larger orders and increased access to hospitals in the broader market, companies have reevaluated how to expand access. Some companies have expanded their distributor networks to create the potential for larger orders from hospitals or have invested in wider sales coverage to pursue and serve customers they previously could not reach. Others are bringing the distributor function in-house, consolidating provincial warehouse operations, and assessing distributors capabilities to define rolesfollowed by agreement on how tighter margins will be shared. Across the board, companies are more proactively managing their distributors and assessing the economics of that channel.</p>
<h3>Reassessing and reallocating commercial resources</h3>
<p>Despite its slowing growth pace, Chinas market for medtech continues to offer huge potential. Companies that prove nimbler in redeploying management and sales resources to emerging product categories of high-growth innovation will likely outperform competitors that remain too focused on established categories.</p>
<p>In 2022, for example, Boston Scientific unveiled a series of innovative products, such as the Rezm water vapor system for treating enlarged prostate glands. It also has put more resources into supporting new products.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc172403-fb0f-48d5-8408-90bfc2d6ec16"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc172403-fb0f-48d5-8408-90bfc2d6ec16" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Two products of Boston Scientific have been approved for launch using Hainan Lecheng real-world data, PEOPLE.CN, March 5, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> As another example, in response to the national VBP classifying coronary drug-eluting stents as a commodity, Abbott Laboratories pared sales staff supporting that product. Furthermore, the companys focus on innovative continuous glucose monitors has increased annual sales for the monitors to more than $100 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d6814809-2a60-41ba-8330-253ba8a58225"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d6814809-2a60-41ba-8330-253ba8a58225" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Disappearing medical device distributors, MedTrend, QQ, February 18, 2022; Yang Xue, The blood sugar market exploded, Abbott sold 20 billion RMB single product globally, and the domestic four companies are competing in the 10 billion market, VBData, July 6, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Divesting commoditized assets or outsourcing them for a new company to distribute is also a potential path forward. In pharmaceuticals, as companies reduce costs, they can generate revenues by licensing out their less-differentiated products that have recorded declining profits. For example, Eli Lilly sold two commodity antibiotics and its corresponding Suzhou plant to Eddingpharm, a specialty pharmaceuticals manufacturer in Shanghai. In all cases, sales force synergy, partnership feasibility, and financial potential need to be carefully evaluated. Divesting or outsourcing assets might result in lower revenue in situations where manufacturers would need to share more margin with partners. In contrast, prospects for profits might be higher if those assets are retained under the existing model.</p>
<p>Overall, bottom-up sales and marketing analysis is essential to reassess commercial performance, understand cost-to-serve among portfolios, and strategize how to reallocate resources and investments. These steps will need to be considered with channel restructuring because adjustments will determine the workloads of the internal sales force.</p>
<h3>Broadening omnichannel customer engagement</h3>
<p>Better coordination of customer engagements across different channels, enabled by data and analytics, will help make sales operations more efficient in casting a wider net and enhancing customer experience.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5cdfdc72-3583-450a-a1c6-d9983ed22415"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5cdfdc72-3583-450a-a1c6-d9983ed22415" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/omnichannel-engagement-in-medtech-the-time-is-now">Omnichannel engagement in medtech: The time is now</a>, McKinsey, May 19, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Most medtech companies in China do connect with customers in multiple channels, both online and offline, but they rarely have coordinated engagement across channels. Efforts often are scattered among teams in marketing, sales, service, and distribution. Valuable insights created by each team from ongoing customer engagements are not promptly shared or made accessible.</p>
<p>To cite one common shortfall, marketing teams have made efforts in priority customer engagements involving online webinars and live streaming projects, but they often do not properly track, assess, and transfer all possible leads generated from digital marketing. Thus, they miss an opportunity to better equip frontline sales teams to follow up and be responsive to customer needs or questions.</p>
<p>Companies need to update and improve how their different departments communicate and work together. Crucial elements for sharpening omnichannel customer engagement include appropriately sharing data across functions and fostering collaboration among cross-functional teams to analyze the implications of that data. These changes can transform the fundamental ways an organization works.</p>
<p>Sales force capabilities and constraints are another challenge, especially when medtech companies expand into smaller (lower-tier) cities or markets for volume-based pricing products. Broadly speaking, companies in these circumstances need to take two important steps. First, they could learn fromand archive for easy accessintelligence from customer interactions across all the channels. Second, they could leverage data and analytics engines to better synchronize next-best actions with improved customer engagement effectiveness.</p>
<h3>Partnering with other companies to expand possibilities</h3>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>More partnerships, diverse stakeholders, and sources of solutions</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>New alliances</strong> are helping traditional healthcare participants expand operations through various collaborations and, in many cases, build further momentum with domestic and multinational (MNC) medtech companies to pursue high-growth markets.</p>
<p>Ecosystem 1.0  The Era of Expansion is a pragmatic alliance that involves traditional stakeholders, including government organizations, academic institutions, service providers, payers, investors, distributors, contractors, and other manufacturers.</p>
<p>As partnerships take shape, companies can expedite access to innovative offerings, broaden customer coverage with diverse commercial models, and achieve new options for manufacturing. In one case, Siemens Healthineers of Germany established a strategic collaboration with Shanghai Electric. They will jointly develop and localize medical equipment in China and accelerate penetration into grassroots healthcare institutions. In another case, Illumina, the global leader in groundbreaking sequencing and array technologies, partnered with Sequoia Capital to launch a genomics incubator in China.</p>
<p>A broader, more diverse set of stakeholders has coalesced and joined medtech companies in China to shape Ecosystem 2.0  The Era of Transformation. Chinas 14th Five-Year Plan articulates the urgency to spur partnerships by integrating global resources and pathbreaking digital technologies, including 5G, AI, and IoT.</p>
<p>Domestic companies and MNCs with domestic operations are embracing proven innovations by companies with headquarters beyond Chinas borders to expand their offerings in high-growth product lines. Medtech licensing deals that were rarely observed three years ago have become more common.</p>
<p>New solutions are increasingly coming from collaborations with digital or AI companies and analytic integrators of data gathered from actual clinical outcomes. For example, Koninklijke Philips and Chinese online medical company Hongyun Rongtong agreed to jointly create a telemedicine platform to promote the adoption of high-quality medical resources by hospitals in smaller cities. Medtech companies can also learn from other industries, as innovators in many industries do. For example, an executive at Tencent, one of Chinas most renowned internet and technology companies, said at a recent conference that its Intelligent Mobility unit benefits from a rich auto service ecology that encompasses about 40 auto manufacturers and the more than 150 models they offer.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Medtech companies in China have built partnerships and combined complementary strengths to capture value along the patient journey from prevention, diagnosis, and treatment to disease management in patient homes or outpatient clinics after treatment. Through these new relationships, manufacturers benefit from the network effect as escalating ranks of participants create the potential for more appealing opportunities (see sidebar, More partnerships, diverse stakeholders, and sources of solutions).</p>
<p>However, not all partnerships will prove to be sufficiently rewarded. How can companies best balance investment decisions and benefits returned? This remains an important question. A holistic assessment and the prioritization of ecosystem projects are essential to the success of medtech companies.</p>
<h3>Staying true to the basics of commercial excellence</h3>
<p>The basics in commercial excellence are becoming even more important as margin pressure grows and the quality of domestic companies improves.</p>
<p>Setting priorities for customer segments and allocating resources creatively and with discipline are essential to strengthening market positions. To be sure, changes in the landscape of healthcare providers in China have been dynamic. Yet, in some ways, the biggest factorthe expansion of large healthcare providers for patientshas not changed. More than 3,000 Class III hospitals (with 3.2 million beds)those that offer comprehensive levels of care and sophisticated proceduresstill contribute 56 percent of patient flow.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="466fe5ca-ca91-45f0-a9ba-5b474387e1ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="466fe5ca-ca91-45f0-a9ba-5b474387e1ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of data from the statistics center of the NHC.</span></span></span></a></span> Recent government policies, such as tiered medical-system reforms and funding support, have diverted patient growth volume toward these large institutions in smaller cities.</p>
<p>Other priority basics include differentiating commercial models by product categories, optimizing sales responsibilities and coverage, and creating excellence in pricing. These fundamentals often do not get the attention they deserve. For example, capital equipment offerings should be linked to customer solutions. Leading medtech companies continue to benefit by providing educational programs with information that is valued by medical professionals, especially those featuring new products used in new procedures. Moreover, cost efficiencies are critical for products that have few differentiating elements. As mentioned above, these products often are candidates to be sold or discontinued after trade-offs are assessed.</p>
<p>Before starting reviews of these basics, leaders could consider a systematic value-oriented assessment: What do our distribution channels cost? Are we allocating resources in line with our strategic priorities?</p>
<hr>
<p>Transforming the commercial model requires fundamental changes for medtech companies in China aspiring to win their share of the markets alluring opportunities for growth. By embracing the five levers outlined in this article, they can strengthen a foundation for success in the new dynamics driving the nations evolving market for medtech.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Jody Tian</strong> is a partner in McKinseys Hong Kong office, <strong>Wei Wei</strong> is a senior expert in the Shanghai office, <strong>Kevin Y Wu</strong> is a partner in the Beijing office, and <strong>Delphine Zurkiya</strong> is a senior partner in the Boston office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Franck Le Deu and Peter Pfeiffer for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 growth in medtech: The next surge in portfolio moves</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Upgrading medtech commercial operations in China","displayName":"Upgrading medtech commercial operations in China","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"f898197d-ba7a-4bd5-aebe-eda8bc474449","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Upgrading medtech commercial operations in China"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Growth in China\u0026rsquo;s buoyant medtech market is tapering as policy uncertainties persist. Five approaches to refocus commercial operations can help navigate these challenges."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Five approaches to refocus commercial operations could boost growth for companies selling medical devices in China."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-03-13T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eChina\u0026rsquo;s burgeoning market\u003c/strong\u003e for medtech, estimated at $70 billion in 2021,[[footnote 1]] could more than double this decade if the government\u0026rsquo;s Healthy China 2030 plan stays on track. The plan projects 9 percent annual spending growth through this decade.[[footnote 2]] This is significant. That growth would lift China\u0026rsquo;s healthcare spending as a percentage of GDP to almost equal footing with some developed economies in Europe and would lift China\u0026rsquo;s medtech market to about 20 percent of the global market by 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChina could remain the world\u0026rsquo;s most appealing growth market for medtech. The growth pace, however, has slowed, and uncertainties facing business leaders are likely to continue. While multinational medtech participants in China and domestic companies in this critical industry continue to deliver essential healthcare goods and services, they need to rethink\u0026mdash;and, in most cases, restructure\u0026mdash;their commercial operations in response to the new market dynamics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe old model was geared for rapid (even sprawling) expansion\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany multinational companies (MNCs) and domestic companies in China\u0026rsquo;s once surging medtech market thrived under a commercial model that valued multiple layers in the sales force and sprawling networks of numerous distributors; financial rigor was secondary. The old model came into fashion when annual growth rates for the industry averaged 15 percent in the first decade of this century and more than 10 percent in the second decade (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis model needs to be reexamined. Medtech companies could look to redeploy resources with financial discipline in ways that sustain growth, improve efficiency, and deliver better products and services to customers and patients. They are operating in a new pricing and competitive landscape that has more diverse stakeholders and requires more discipline and innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn some areas, domestic companies are markedly improving their performance across their operations. China\u0026rsquo;s 134 listed medtech companies generated $44 billion in 2021 revenues, an impressive CAGR of 36 percent since 2019\u0026mdash;nearly triple the market\u0026rsquo;s overall rate of growth. More than five Chinese medtech companies have obtained the FDA\u0026rsquo;s breakthrough designation, which helps expedite the development, assessment and review of novel medical devices that can potentially provide more effective treatment or that diagnose life-threatening or irreversibly debilitating diseases or conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePolicy reforms have shifted the old model\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall GDP growth in China slowed to 3.0 percent in 2022 and is expected to rise only modestly to 4.5 to 5.5 percent in 2023.[[footnote 3]] The government paid high prices for medtech equipment and services, which were a factor in attracting many of the world\u0026rsquo;s leading MNCs to China in the last two decades. However, after years of generous criteria for payments, recent\u0026nbsp;reforms in the government\u0026rsquo;s procurement and medical insurance programs have shifted\u0026nbsp;much of the old model. For example, the price for drug-eluting stents used in cardiac surgery was cut by more than 90 percent after reforms in 2021, decreasing to $100 from a previous range of $1,400 to $2,100.[[footnote 4]] As a result, hospitals face significant cost constraints, especially for less differentiated, commoditized products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFive levers for transforming the medtech commercial model in China\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultinational and domestic medtech companies could consider reevaluating their commercial model to sustain or increase growth in China, focusing on five interlinked functions in operations:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003echannel restructuring to prepare for the price-sensitive environment while expanding coverage to sustain the growth\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ecommercial resources reassessment to adapt to evolving strategic priorities and outperform the market\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eomnichannel customer engagement to improve sales efficiency, broaden reach, and enhance customer experience\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eecosystem partnerships to develop new innovation engines and deliver integrated solutions to a broader customer base\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ea focus on the basics to cope with margin pressure and the rise of local players\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich of these levers is most difficult to pull? Which one can be a source of competitive advantage even for companies that have already started channel reforms or partnership scouting? There isn\u0026rsquo;t a singular answer. The optimal response will vary by segments and companies. Business leaders will need to explore suitable approaches with appropriate levels of emphasis and execution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn our view, complex channel restructuring is most urgent for companies that relied heavily on high-markup distributors and for those whose portfolios were most affected by the  government-mandated price drop (reforms known as volume-based procurement [VBP][[footnote 5]]). That said, VBP has created opportunities to serve broader markets. To tap into them, companies will also need effective ways to acquire new customers and retain existing ones via an omnichannel approach. Moreover, innovating through license-in and partnership agreements can help propel sustainable growth in the mid to long term. As VBP and trends in the macroeconomy ease the overall pace of revenue momentum in medtech, companies need to plan now to avoid having to continually put out fires in the near term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies will also need to strengthen capabilities along the levers. For example, companies that have historically focused on consumables and that are now seeking to add equipment into their portfolio will need to recruit distributors with experience in engaging nonclinical stakeholders. They will also need to reassess their sales capabilities and resource allocation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGreat companies excel in this analysis. They can assess early the development needs for each lever, precisely identify the real source of advantage, efficiently transform commercial capabilities and models, and successfully outpace market growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRestructuring the channels for customer touch points\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a nation with more than 36,500 hospitals to care for 1.4 billion people,[[footnote 6]] the landscape of medtech companies and distributors has been fragmented. Distributors, together with the internal sales force of manufacturers, have largely acted as representatives to manufacturers\u0026rsquo; customers, the hospitals, and clinics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo forces in the new economics of China\u0026rsquo;s healthcare system are upending these roles and responsibilities. First, VBP is sharply reducing margins left to distributors. Bidders are expected to cut price-to-hospital[[footnote 7]] by more than 50 percent to win contracts. Second, as they pertain to medical insurance payments, reforms[[footnote 8]] tied to diagnosis-related group or diagnosis intervention packet (DRG/DIP) have a compounding effect in reducing the profit margins of manufacturers and distributors. In certain product categories, smaller distributors that are unable to navigate these shifts profitably have already walked away. Distribution consolidation  is evident. Sinopharm, for example, the largest healthcare distributor in China, reported a 21 percent increase to $17 billion for medtech revenues in 2021. Its expanding customer roster of manufacturers includes global leaders such as Medtronic, Johnson \u0026amp; Johnson, Danaher, Becton Dickinson, Stryker, and Smith+Nephew.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMedtech companies are responding to reforms by reevaluating their relationships with distributors. Roles and responsibilities are being reshaped as more companies are adapting to the new economics and sharply lowering payments they can offer distributors (Exhibit 2). Some have narrowed the tasks for platform distributors to only managing logistics and handling accounts receivable.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eSince VBP reforms created the potential for larger orders and increased access to hospitals in the broader market, companies have reevaluated how to expand access. Some companies have expanded their distributor networks to create the potential for larger orders from hospitals or have invested in wider sales coverage to pursue and serve customers they previously could not reach. Others are bringing the distributor function in-house, consolidating provincial warehouse operations, and assessing distributors\u0026rsquo; capabilities to define roles\u0026mdash;followed by agreement on how tighter margins will be shared. Across the board, companies are more proactively managing their distributors and assessing the economics of that channel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReassessing and reallocating commercial resources\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite its slowing growth pace, China\u0026rsquo;s market for medtech continues to offer huge potential. Companies that prove nimbler in redeploying management and sales resources to emerging product categories of high-growth innovation will likely outperform competitors that remain too focused on established categories.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 2022, for example, Boston Scientific unveiled a series of innovative products, such as the Rezm water vapor system for treating enlarged prostate glands. It also has put more resources into supporting new products.[[footnote 9]] As another example, in response to the national VBP classifying coronary drug-eluting stents as a commodity, Abbott Laboratories pared sales staff supporting that product. Furthermore, the company\u0026rsquo;s focus on innovative continuous glucose monitors has increased annual sales for the monitors to more than $100 million.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDivesting commoditized assets or outsourcing them for a new company to distribute is also a potential path forward. In pharmaceuticals, as companies reduce costs, they can generate revenues by licensing out their less-differentiated products that have recorded declining profits. For example, Eli Lilly sold two commodity antibiotics and its corresponding Suzhou plant to Eddingpharm, a specialty pharmaceuticals manufacturer in Shanghai. In all cases, sales force synergy, partnership feasibility, and financial potential need to be carefully evaluated. Divesting or outsourcing assets might result in lower revenue in situations where manufacturers would need to share more margin with partners. In contrast, prospects for profits might be higher if those assets are retained under the existing model.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, bottom-up sales and marketing analysis is essential to reassess commercial performance, understand cost-to-serve among portfolios, and strategize how to reallocate resources and investments. These steps will need to be considered with channel restructuring because adjustments will determine the workloads of the internal sales force.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBroadening omnichannel customer engagement\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetter coordination of customer engagements across different channels, enabled by data and analytics, will help make sales operations more efficient in casting a wider net and enhancing customer experience.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost medtech companies in China do connect with customers in multiple channels, both online and offline, but they rarely have coordinated engagement across channels. Efforts often are scattered among teams in marketing, sales, service, and distribution. Valuable insights created by each team from ongoing customer engagements are not promptly shared or made accessible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo cite one common shortfall, marketing teams have made efforts in priority customer engagements involving online webinars and live streaming projects, but they often do not properly track, assess, and transfer all possible leads generated from digital marketing. Thus, they miss an opportunity to better equip frontline sales teams to follow up and be responsive to customer needs or questions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies need to update and improve how their different departments communicate and work together. Crucial elements for sharpening omnichannel customer engagement include appropriately sharing data across functions and fostering collaboration among cross-functional teams to analyze the implications of that data. These changes can transform the fundamental ways an organization works.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSales force capabilities and constraints are another challenge, especially when medtech companies expand into smaller (lower-tier) cities or markets for volume-based pricing products. Broadly speaking, companies in these circumstances need to take two important steps. First, they could learn from\u0026mdash;and archive for easy access\u0026mdash;intelligence from customer interactions across all the channels. Second, they could leverage data and analytics engines to better synchronize next-best actions with improved customer engagement effectiveness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePartnering with other companies to expand possibilities\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMedtech companies in China have built partnerships and combined complementary strengths to capture value along the patient journey from prevention, diagnosis, and treatment to disease management in patient homes or outpatient clinics after treatment. Through these new relationships, manufacturers benefit from the network effect as escalating ranks of participants create the potential for more appealing opportunities (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;More partnerships, diverse stakeholders, and sources of solutions\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, not all partnerships will prove to be sufficiently rewarded. How can companies best balance investment decisions and benefits returned? This remains an important question. A holistic assessment and the prioritization of ecosystem projects are essential to the success of medtech companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStaying true to the basics of commercial excellence\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe basics in commercial excellence are becoming even more important as margin pressure grows and the quality of domestic companies improves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSetting priorities for customer segments and allocating resources creatively and with discipline are essential to strengthening market positions. To be sure, changes in the landscape of healthcare providers in China have been dynamic. Yet, in some ways, the biggest factor\u0026mdash;the expansion of large healthcare providers for patients\u0026mdash;has not changed. More than 3,000 Class III hospitals (with 3.2 million beds)\u0026mdash;those that offer comprehensive levels of care and sophisticated procedures\u0026mdash;still contribute 56 percent of patient flow.[[footnote 12]] Recent government policies, such as tiered medical-system reforms and funding support, have diverted patient growth volume toward these large institutions in smaller cities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther priority basics include differentiating commercial models by product categories, optimizing sales responsibilities and coverage, and creating excellence in pricing. These fundamentals often do not get the attention they deserve. For example, capital equipment offerings should be linked to customer solutions. Leading medtech companies continue to benefit by providing educational programs with information that is valued by medical professionals, especially those featuring new products used in new procedures. Moreover, cost efficiencies are critical for products that have few differentiating elements. As mentioned above, these products often are candidates to be sold or discontinued after trade-offs are assessed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore starting reviews of these basics, leaders could consider a systematic value-oriented assessment: What do our distribution channels cost? Are we allocating resources in line with our strategic priorities?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTransforming the commercial model requires fundamental changes for medtech companies in China aspiring to win their share of the market\u0026rsquo;s alluring opportunities for growth. By embracing the five levers outlined in this article, they can strengthen a foundation for success in the new dynamics driving the nation\u0026rsquo;s evolving market for medtech.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-03-13T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBased on McKinsey analysis of National Health Commission (NHC) data and annual reports regarding revenue of more than 150 medtech companies and their market share.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBased on McKinsey analysis of National Health Commission (NHC) data and annual reports regarding revenue of more than 150 medtech companies and their market share.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;The director of the National Bureau of Statistics answered reporters\u0026rsquo; questions on the national economic operation in 2022,\u0026rdquo; National Bureau of Statistics, January 17, 2023. helping traditional healthcare participants expand operations through various collaborations and, in many cases, build further momentum with domestic and multinational (MNC) medtech companies to pursue high-growth markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEcosystem 1.0 \u0026ndash; The Era of Expansion is a pragmatic alliance that involves traditional stakeholders, including government organizations, academic institutions, service providers, payers, investors, distributors, contractors, and other manufacturers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs partnerships take shape, companies can expedite access to innovative offerings, broaden customer coverage with diverse commercial models, and achieve new options for manufacturing. In one case, Siemens Healthineers of Germany established a strategic collaboration with Shanghai Electric. They will jointly develop and localize medical equipment in China and accelerate penetration into grassroots healthcare institutions. In another case, Illumina, the global leader in groundbreaking sequencing and array technologies, partnered with Sequoia Capital to launch a genomics incubator in China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA broader, more diverse set of stakeholders has coalesced and joined medtech companies in China to shape Ecosystem 2.0 \u0026ndash; The Era of Transformation. China\u0026rsquo;s 14th Five-Year Plan articulates the urgency to spur partnerships by integrating global resources and pathbreaking digital technologies, including 5G, AI, and IoT.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDomestic companies and MNCs with domestic operations are embracing proven innovations by companies with headquarters beyond China\u0026rsquo;s borders to expand their offerings in high-growth product lines. Medtech licensing deals that were rarely observed three years ago have become more common.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew solutions are increasingly coming from collaborations with digital or AI companies and analytic integrators of data gathered from actual clinical outcomes. For example, Koninklijke Philips and Chinese online medical company Hongyun Rongtong agreed to jointly create a telemedicine platform to promote the adoption of high-quality medical resources by hospitals in smaller cities. Medtech companies can also learn from other industries, as innovators in many industries do. For example, an executive at Tencent, one of China\u0026rsquo;s most renowned internet and technology companies, said at a recent conference that its Intelligent Mobility unit benefits from \u0026ldquo;a rich auto service ecology\u0026rdquo; that encompasses about 40 auto manufacturers and the more than 150 models they
